Award.AwardTitle: MaizeCode - An Initial Analysis of Functional Elements in the Maize Genome
Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Thomas Gingeras (Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory)

CoPIs: David Jackson, Robert Martienssen, W. Richard McCombie, Michael Schatz, and David Micklos (Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory), Doreen Ware (USDA-ARS/Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory); and Ken Birnbaum (New York University)

Maize (corn) is one of the most economically and agriculturally important crops grown in the world. It has assumed this position after centuries of careful genetic breeding to enhance many of its growth and nutritional properties. The generation of high quality genome sequences paired with diverse molecular data allows scientists to better understand the effects of this selective breeding at both the genetic and epigenetic levels. The MaizeCODE project aims to create a comprehensive reference encyclopedia of highly useful genomic reference sequence resources for breeders and plant scientists to use to improve economically important crop traits like disease resistance and yield. In addition, this project will provide broad and comprehensive training opportunities for students, breeders and practicing scientists through specific courses and workshops that will address various approaches to obtain and analyze MaizeCODE data. The Education, Outreach, and Training (EOT) effort will prepare faculty from primarily undergraduate institutions (PUIs) to analyze MaizeCODE with undergraduate students and will provide travel awards for graduate students to attend MaizeCODE training at professional meetings. The EOT program will be unique in promoting Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM) disciplines by anticipating and encouraging broad participation in primary data analysis by undergraduate and graduate students.

Improved assemblies of the maize genome will provide a foundation for the identification of biochemically active and biologically functional elements encoded in this working-draft sequence. A comprehensive catalog of these elements will be a critical component in strategies to link genotype with important traits in maize, a classical genetic system. This is the overarching goal of the MaizeCODE project. The human ENCODE project is a model for such a comprehensive catalog. Building on the project team's leadership experience with ENCODE, this similarly integrated and multi-disciplinary project has three main objectives: 1) to develop high-quality working drafts for two inbred maze lines and one teosinte inbred line, 2) to identify regions of the maize genome that are transcribed, methylated, bound by specific modified histones in six cell types that are the major progenitors of the root and shoot systems (focusing on histone modification in three root cell types) and transcription factors in five unrelated tissues and 3) to store, collate, display and disseminate the data to the broader community of plant biologists worldwide. Given the wealth of "genome to phenome" studies in maize, and the emerging realization that much of the variation under selection acts at the level of gene regulation, it is expected that this project will have broad and significant impact on maize genetics research and breeding, with the potential to inform similar research in other grass crops. The project expects to extend significantly the functional annotations and the current understanding of the regulation of gene activity in maize, adding critical content to established databases and graphical genome display centers. Information generated in this project will be rapidly and broadly disseminated using publically available databases and the CyVerse (www.cyverse.org) online resource.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The aims of the no-cost extension work covering the period of 06-01-20 to 05-31-21 focused on five tasks. The first task was the completion of the sequencing, assembly and annotation) of the Til 11 genome using both long (PacBio) and short (Illumina) read sequencing. Using B73 (v4) as a reference a total of 18,438 structural variants (SV) affecting 55.58 Mb of the genome which is similar to 19,455 SV affecting 60.13 Mb in the NC 350 which we sequenced in the main portion of the project.

The second task was carried out at the bulk tissue level and involved the acquisition of antibody reagents (for H3K4me1, H3K4me3, HeK27ac modifications) that would be used in a chromatin immuno-precipitation sequencing (ChIP-seq) experiments. These experiments were done to identify (promoter and enhancer), to locate (proximal and distal from genes) and to determine the state (active or repressed) of regulatory regions in three maize accessions. Chromatin modification profiles were carried out on endosperm and immature ears of B73, on endosperm for NC350 and immature ears on Til11. Approximately 25% of the reads mapped uniquely, 70-74% displayed multiple mapping sites and the rest (5-<1%) were unmapped. These data were then integrated with the data base of functional elements collected in the main period of the MaizeCode project (see fourth task, below)

The third and fourth tasks were focused at the single cell level using fluorescent-activated cell sorting, RNA sequencing and in situ hybridization. The goal of the third task was to map the transcriptome of single cells from the roots of B73 to uncover the mechanism that regulates cortex cell layer number. (manuscript under review) The fourth task focused on the development an atlas of the individual cell types composing the maize ears during inflorescence (Dev Cell 2021: 56:557). Additionally, using ChIP-seq, the genome-wide binding sites for 9 transcription factors (TF) that are important for ear development have been mapped for B73.

The fifth task was to conduct an integrated analysis of the data collected over the course of the entire MaizeCode project including the data from this no-cost extension.  The integrated analyses used a broad spectrum of experimental data including: RNA-seq (long [> 200 nucleotides] short [<200 nts}, RAMPAGE (identifying 5? termini of long transcripts), and ChIPseq (chromatin modifications- see task 2 above) Of the approximate 19,000-24,000 differentially expressed genes (DEG) in each of the five tissue types found in 4 accessions, a significant level of corresponding correlation is observed of active and repressed chromatin modifications is observed. This lends support to the observations of modifications at unannotated candidate enhancer loci. These analyses are being used to identify distal enhancers and the genes they regulate. Finally, the intersection of DEG and their TF regulators with their evolutionary conservation (i.e. Til 11 vs inbreed accessions) is being explored as possible actors in maize domestication.

Finally, to provide both human and machine access to all of the MaizeCODE project data, we have been made available on CyVerse, (a NSF funded platform to be used in an unrestricted fashion).  QC and preliminary analysis are being done through SciApps.org, a cloud-based workflow platform powered by both the CyVerse Data Store for storage and Texas Advanced Computing Center (TACC) for computing. tools, workflows, and genomic data from multiple projects. Through metadata and a ready-to-compute cloud-based platform, the portal experience improves access to the MaizeCODE data and facilitates its analysis (Front in Plant Sci. 2020: 11:289).
